title: 807 Ceraskia
text:
807 Ceraskia (<a href="Minor%20planet%20provisional%20designation">"prov. designation"</a>: "or" ) is an elongated <a href="Eos%20asteroid">Eos asteroid</a> from the outer regions of the <a href="asteroid%20belt">asteroid belt</a>. It was discovered on 18 April 1915, by German astronomer <a href="Max%20Wolf">Max Wolf</a> at the <a href="Heidelberg-K%C3%B6nigstuhl%20State%20Observatory">Heidelberg-Königstuhl State Observatory</a> in southwest Germany. The <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-type asteroid</a> has a <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of 7.4 hours and measures approximately in diameter. It was named after Belarusian–Soviet astronomer <a href="Vitold%20Cerasky">Vitold Cerasky</a> (1849–1925).
Orbit and classification.
"Ceraskia" is a core member the <a href="Eos%20family">Eos family</a> (), the largest <a href="asteroid%20family">asteroid family</a> of the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">outer</a> main belt consisting of nearly 10,000 known asteroids. It orbits the Sun in the <a href="Kirkwood%20gap">outer</a> asteroid belt at a distance of 2.8–3.2 <a href="Astronomical%20unit">AU</a> once every 5 years and 3 months (1,913 days; <a href="semi-major%20axis">semi-major axis</a> of 3.02 AU). Its orbit has an <a href="orbital%20eccentricity">eccentricity</a> of 0.07 and an <a href="orbital%20inclination">inclination</a> of 11<a href="Degree%20%28angle%29">°</a> with respect to the <a href="ecliptic">ecliptic</a>. The asteroid was first observed as at <a href="Heidelberg%20Observatory">Heidelberg Observatory</a> on 18 January 1909. The body's <a href="observation%20arc">observation arc</a> begins at <a href="Vienna%20Observatory">Vienna Observatory</a> on 4 May 1915, or two weeks after its official discovery observation at Heidelberg by Max Wolf.
Naming.
This <a href="minor%20planet">minor planet</a> was named after <a href="Vitold%20Cerasky">Vitold Cerasky</a> (1849–1925), a Belarusian–Soviet astronomer, professor of astronomy at <a href="Moscow%20University">Moscow University</a> and long-time director of the Moscow Observatory . According to <a href="Nikolai%20Chernykh">Nikolai Chernykh</a>, Cerasky worked extensively on stellar and solar <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometry</a>. His name is often transliterated as Vitold Tserasky and Witold Karlovich Ceraski. The lunar crater <a href="Tseraskiy%20%28crater%29">"Tseraskiy"</a> is named after him. His wife, <a href="Lidiya%20Tseraskaya">Lidiya Tseraskaya</a> (1855–1931), who was also an astronomer, was honored by the crater <a href="List%20of%20craters%20on%20Venus%23Tseraskaya">"Tseraskaya"</a> on Venus.
The was incorrect in the previous three editions of "Dictionary of Minor Planet Names", which was based on "<a href="The%20Names%20of%20the%20Minor%20Planets">The Names of the Minor Planets</a>" by <a href="Paul%20Herget">Paul Herget</a> in 1955 ().
Physical characteristics.
In the <a href="Tholen%20classification">Tholen classification</a>, "Ceraskia" is a common, stony <a href="S-type%20asteroid">S-type asteroid</a>. In the taxonomic classification based on near-infrared colors from the MOVIS-catalog, the asteroid is a Cgx-subtype that is closest to a carbonaceous <a href="C-type%20asteroid">C-type</a> and somewhat similar to a uncommon <a href="G-type%20asteroid">G-type</a> and <a href="X-type%20asteroid">X-type asteroid</a>. The MOVIS catalog was created from data gather by the <a href="VISTA%20%28telescope%29%23VISTA%20Surveys">VISTA Hemisphere Survey</a> conducted with the <a href="VISTA%20%28telescope%29">VISTA</a> telescope at <a href="Paranal%20Observatory">Paranal Observatory</a> in Chile.
Rotation period.
In October 2017, a rotational <a href="lightcurve">lightcurve</a> of "Ceraskia" was obtained from <a href="Photometry%20%28astronomy%29">photometric</a> observations by Matthieu Conjat at <a href="Nice%20Observatory">Nice Observatory</a> in France. Lightcurve analysis gave a well-defined <a href="rotation%20period">rotation period</a> of hours with a brightness variation of <a href="Magnitude%20%28astronomy%29">magnitude</a> (). The result supersedes previous observations by <a href="Richard%20Binzel">Richard Binzel</a> in April 1983 and by astronomers at the <a href="Palomar%20Transient%20Factory">Palomar Transient Factory</a> in California on October 2012, which gave a period of and hours with an amplitude of and magnitude, respectively ().
Lightcurve inversion also modeled the body's shape and <a href="Poles%20of%20astronomical%20bodies">poles</a>. In 2013, modelling by an international study using photometric data from the <a href="US%20Naval%20Observatory">US Naval Observatory</a>, the Uppsala Asteroid Photometric Catalogue, the <a href="Palomar%20Transient%20Factory">Palomar Transient Factory</a> and the <a href="Catalina%20Sky%20Survey">Catalina Sky Survey</a> gave a concurring sidereal period of hours and two spin axes of (325.0°, 23.0°) and (132.0°, 26.0°) in <a href="Ecliptic%20coordinate%20system">ecliptic coordinates</a> (λ, β). The body's very elongated shape had already been indicated by the relatively high brightness variation measured during the direct photometric observations.
Diameter and albedo.
According to the surveys carried out by the <a href="NEOWISE">NEOWISE</a> mission of NASA's <a href="Wide-field%20Infrared%20Survey%20Explorer">Wide-field Infrared Survey Explorer</a> (WISE), the Infrared Astronomical Satellite <a href="IRAS">IRAS</a>, and the Japanese <a href="Akari%20%28satellite%29">Akari satellite</a>, "Ceraskia" measures (), () and () kilometers in diameter and its surface has an <a href="astronomical%20albedo">albedo</a> of (), () and (), respectively. The "Collaborative Asteroid Lightcurve Link" derives an albedo of 0.1368 and a diameter of 26.15 kilometers based on an <a href="absolute%20magnitude">absolute magnitude</a> of 10.69.
